results.justification: The document explicitly states the introduction of "Transition Network Analysis (TNA)" and its integration of Stochastic Process Mining (SPM) and probabilistic network (PN) models.
Sections 3.1 (Implementation of the method) and subsequent subsections detail the steps taken, including data coding, session grouping, Markov model estimation, clustering, and covariate analysis.
The document states the data was gathered from course offerings but does not provide a link or mention availability of the raw or processed datasets. No justification for non-sharing is given.
Table 1 provides a coding scheme for chat discussions, acting as a data dictionary explaining the variables and codes used.

The document describes the data collection as students collaborating online using chats, and specifies the course level and number of participants. It also details the coding process and inter-rater reliability (κ>0.61).
The document mentions the use of the R package 'tna' [19] and 'seqHMM' [12, 37], implying code availability.
The document details the steps for data preparation, including coding, session grouping, and Markov model estimation, which could be replicated with the mentioned R packages.

The document describes statistical methods like Markov models, clustering (BIC values reported), covariate analysis (estimates, confidence intervals, p-values reported), and centrality measures. Effect sizes (e.g., t-values) are also reported.

While the data originates from text (chat discussions), the analysis focuses on quantitative modeling of the coded data. There is limited subjective context or interpretation beyond describing the model results.
The document does not mention or link to any preregistration.
The document presents detailed results of the TNA analysis, including network plots, centrality measures, cluster characteristics, and covariate analysis results.

The document explicitly discusses limitations related to sample size, Markov model assumptions, computational complexity, and potential issues with continuous-time processes. It also cautions about the context-sensitivity of network measures.
